items.title: Scratches Showing On Plastic? Use 220 Grit For Surface Prep
items.description: If plastic scratches keep showing, 220 grit helps level the surface and reduce visible marks before paint or coating. Sand lightly with even pressure, then wipe clean and inspect under light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Feels Too Rough? Use 180 Grit To Smooth It
items.description: When plastic feels too rough, 180 grit helps knock down texture and even out the surface before primer, paint, or epoxy. Use light pressure and overlapping passes, then wipe clean to check progress. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Surface Not Ready For Paint? Use 220 Grit For Plastic Prep
items.description: If paint prep on plastic feels incomplete, 220 grit creates an even scuff so primer and paint can grip. Sand gently, keep the sheet flat, then wipe with a clean cloth before coating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Uneven After Cutting? Level It With 180 Grit
items.description: After cutting, plastic can look uneven along the surface. 180 grit helps level high spots and blend the cut area before finishing. Use short, controlled strokes and check flatness often. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Rough Marks On Plastic? Smooth Them With 220 Grit
items.description: Rough marks on plastic stand out under paint and clear coats. 220 grit helps refine the surface and blend sanding lines. Use even pressure, overlap passes, then wipe clean and inspect under light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Factory Texture On Plastic? Use 180 Grit For Prep
items.description: Many plastics have a factory texture that can show through finishes. 180 grit helps reduce texture and create a more uniform surface for primer, paint, or epoxy. Sand lightly and clean before coating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Feels Wavy? Flatten The Surface With 180 Grit
items.description: If plastic feels wavy, 180 grit can help flatten small high spots and smooth transitions. Use a flat backing pad where possible, sand in a crosshatch pattern, and check progress often. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Deep Plastic Scratches? Step From 150 To 220 Grit
items.description: For scratches that feel too deep, start with 150 grit to reduce the scratch depth, then move to 220 grit to refine the surface before primer or paint. Keep strokes even and wipe clean between steps. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Needs Scuffing? Use 220 Grit For Adhesion
items.description: When plastic needs scuff sanding, 220 grit creates a consistent tooth for primer, paint, and clear coats. Sand lightly, cover edges and curves evenly, then wipe clean before coating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Not Uniform? Even It Out With 180 Grit
items.description: If the plastic surface looks patchy or inconsistent, 180 grit helps even the texture and blend high/low areas before finishing. Use light pressure, overlap passes, and clean the surface to check progress. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Sharp Plastic Edge? Smooth It With 180 Grit
items.description: If plastic edges feel sharp after cutting, 180 grit helps soften the edge and remove burrs. Fold the sheet, sand along the edge with controlled strokes, then wipe clean and re-check by touch. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Uneven After Plastic Repair? Blend With 220 Grit
items.description: After a repair, plastic can look uneven where materials meet. 220 grit helps blend the transition and refine the surface before paint or clear coat. Sand lightly and check often to avoid low spots. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Looks Dull And Rough? Refine With 220 Grit
items.description: If plastic looks dull and rough, 220 grit helps refine the surface and reduce visible sanding lines before primer, paint, or epoxy. Use even strokes, keep pressure light, then wipe clean and inspect. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Coarse Grit Marks Left? Refine Plastic With 220 Grit
items.description: If coarse grit marks are still visible on plastic, switch to 220 grit to refine the scratches and even out the surface before paint or epoxy. Use light pressure, overlap passes, then wipe clean to inspect. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Still Feels Grainy? Finish Prep With 220 Grit
items.description: When plastic still feels grainy after sanding, 220 grit helps smooth the surface and reduce scratch texture before primer, paint, or coating. Sand evenly, then wipe clean and check by touch and light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Need Light Smoothing? Use 320 Grit For Fine Plastic Prep
items.description: For light smoothing on plastic, 320 grit helps refine the surface and reduce fine sanding lines before paint, clear coat, or epoxy. Use gentle pressure and consistent strokes, then wipe clean to inspect. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Surface Too Smooth For Paint? Scuff With 220 Grit
items.description: If plastic is too smooth to grip paint, 220 grit scuff sanding creates a consistent tooth for primer and topcoat. Cover edges and curves evenly, then wipe clean before coating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Feels Inconsistent? Level With 180 Then 220 Grit
items.description: If plastic feels inconsistent, start with 180 grit to level texture and blend high spots, then move to 220 grit to refine the surface before finishing. Wipe clean between steps to track progress. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Scratches Stand Out? Use 220 Grit To Reduce Them
items.description: When scratches stand out on plastic, 220 grit helps reduce their visibility by refining the surface and blending sanding lines before paint or coating. Use light, even strokes and inspect under light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Not Ready For Finish? Prep With 220 Grit
items.description: If plastic isn’t ready for the final finish, 220 grit helps create an even surface and consistent scuff for better coating adhesion. Sand gently, then wipe clean and re-check before applying finish. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Paint Not Sticking? Use 220 Grit For Plastic Prep
items.description: If paint isn’t sticking to plastic, 220 grit scuff sanding helps create a uniform tooth for primer and paint. Sand evenly, including edges, then wipe clean before coating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Paint Peeling Off Plastic? Scuff Properly With 220 Grit
items.description: When paint peels off plastic, the surface is often too slick. 220 grit scuff sanding helps create a consistent texture for primer and paint to grip. Sand lightly, then wipe clean before recoating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Too Smooth For Paint? Use 180 Then 220 Grit
items.description: If plastic is too smooth for paint, start with 180 grit to create an initial scuff, then switch to 220 grit to even out the scratch pattern before primer and paint. Clean between steps. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Fish Eyes In Paint? Prep Plastic With 220 Grit
items.description: If fish eyes show up in paint on plastic, surface prep may be uneven. 220 grit helps create a consistent scuff before priming and painting. Sand lightly, then wipe clean and re-check before coating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Patchy Paint On Plastic? Even Prep With 220 Grit
items.description: If paint looks patchy on plastic, uneven prep is usually the cause. 220 grit scuff sanding helps create a uniform tooth so primer and paint lay down more evenly. Wipe clean before recoating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Paint Shows Every Scratch? Finish Prep With 320 Grit
items.description: When paint highlights every scratch on plastic, refine the surface first. 320 grit helps reduce fine sanding lines for a cleaner final prep before primer and paint. Use light pressure and inspect under light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Primer Not Bonding? Prep Plastic With 220 Grit
items.description: If primer isn’t bonding to plastic, the surface may be too slick or uneven. 220 grit scuff sanding helps create a consistent tooth for primer to grab. Sand evenly, then wipe clean before priming. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Uneven Paint Finish? Smooth Plastic With 220 Grit
items.description: If the paint finish looks uneven on plastic, refine the surface before the next coat. 220 grit helps smooth texture and create an even scuff for better paint laydown. Wipe clean and re-coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Scratches Showing Through Paint? Refine With 320 Grit
items.description: If scratches are showing through paint on plastic, the surface needs finer refinement. 320 grit helps reduce scratch depth and even out sanding lines before priming and repainting. Wipe clean to inspect. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Paint Runs Stand Out? Lightly Scuff Plastic With 320 Grit
items.description: When paint runs stand out on plastic, a light scuff helps the next coat level better. 320 grit is a fine option for gentle scuff sanding without deep scratches. Wipe clean before recoating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Paint Won’t Grip Plastic? Use 180 Then 220 Grit
items.description: If paint won’t grip plastic, build a better scratch pattern. Start with 180 grit to scuff the surface, then switch to 220 grit to even out the sanding lines before primer and paint. Clean between steps. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Gloss Causing Paint Failure? Dull With 220 Grit
items.description: A glossy plastic surface can cause paint failure because it’s too slick. 220 grit scuff sanding helps dull the gloss and create a consistent tooth for primer and paint. Wipe clean before coating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Paint Not Laying Flat? Level Prep With 220 Grit
items.description: If paint isn’t laying flat on plastic, surface prep may be uneven. 220 grit helps level minor texture and create a uniform scuff so paint can lay down smoother. Wipe clean and recoat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Primer Feels Too Smooth? Scuff Plastic Primer With 320 Grit
items.description: If primer feels too smooth on plastic, a light scuff helps the next coat bond better. 320 grit is a fine choice to scuff without adding deep scratches. Sand lightly, then wipe clean before painting. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Paint Flaking On Edges? Prep Plastic Edges With 220 Grit
items.description: If paint is flaking on plastic edges, the edge prep often needs more scuff and cleanup. 220 grit helps prep edges and curves for better primer and paint adhesion. Sand lightly, then wipe clean. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Scratches Visible On Plastic? Reduce Them With 220 Grit
items.description: When scratches are visible on plastic, 220 grit helps refine the scratch pattern and blend sanding lines before paint, clear coat, or epoxy. Use even strokes and check under light between passes. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Fine Scratches Won’t Disappear? Refine With 320 Grit
items.description: If fine scratches won’t disappear on plastic, step up to 320 grit to refine the surface and reduce visible sanding lines before coating. Use light pressure and overlap passes, then wipe clean to inspect. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Deep Scratches In Plastic? Start 180 Then 220 Grit
items.description: For deep scratches in plastic, start with 180 grit to reduce scratch depth, then switch to 220 grit to refine the surface before finishing. Keep strokes even and wipe clean between steps to track progress. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Sanding Marks Still Showing? Refine Plastic With 320 Grit
items.description: If sanding marks are still showing on plastic, 320 grit helps refine the surface and reduce visible scratch lines before coating. Use light pressure, overlap passes, then wipe clean and inspect under light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Looks Scuffed? Smooth Finish With 320 Grit
items.description: If plastic looks scuffed after sanding, 320 grit helps smooth the scratch pattern for a cleaner finish before paint, clear coat, or epoxy. Sand lightly with even strokes, then wipe clean to inspect. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Scratches Stand Out Under Light? Refine With 320 Grit
items.description: If scratches stand out under light on plastic, 320 grit helps refine the surface and reduce visible sanding lines before finishing. Use light, even strokes and inspect often under strong light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Swirl Marks On Plastic? Step 320 To 400 For Cleanup
items.description: If plastic looks swirled after sanding, refine the scratch pattern by stepping from 320 grit to 400 grit. Use light pressure, overlap passes, and wipe clean between grits to track progress under light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Scratches Too Sharp? Soften Plastic Scratches With 220 Grit
items.description: When scratches look too sharp on plastic, 220 grit helps soften the edges of the scratch pattern and blend the surface before primer, paint, or coating. Sand lightly, then wipe clean and inspect under light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Still Looks Scratched? Use 320 Grit Before Polishing Plastic
items.description: If plastic still looks scratched before polishing, refine the surface with 320 grit to reduce visible sanding lines. Use light, even strokes and inspect under light so the polish step works faster and more evenly. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Uneven Scratch Depth? Blend Plastic With 220 Then 320 Grit
items.description: If scratch depth looks uneven on plastic, use 220 grit to level the scratch pattern, then step to 320 grit to refine and blend the surface for a cleaner finish. Wipe clean between steps to inspect. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Scratches Showing After Prep? Finish With 320 Grit
items.description: If plastic scratches still show after prep, 320 grit helps refine the surface and reduce visible sanding lines before paint, clear coat, or epoxy. Sand lightly, then wipe clean and inspect under strong light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Marks Won’t Blend Out? Repair Plastic With 220 To 320 Grit
items.description: If surface marks won’t blend out on plastic, start with 220 grit to reduce the mark edges, then move to 320 grit to refine the scratch pattern for a smoother finish. Clean between steps and re-check. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Sharp Plastic Edges? Smooth Them With 220 Grit
items.description: If plastic edges feel sharp, 220 grit helps smooth the edge and reduce small burrs without leaving deep scratches. Fold the sheet for control and sand along the edge with light strokes. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Hard-To-Sand Corners? Use 220 Grit For Plastic Corners
items.description: Plastic corners can be hard to sand evenly by hand. 220 grit helps refine corners without deep scratches. Fold the sheet into a small pad, use short strokes, and rotate often to avoid gouges. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Edges Melting While Sanding? Use 320 Grit With Light Pressure
items.description: If plastic edges start melting while sanding, friction and pressure are too high. 320 grit with lighter pressure helps control heat and refine the surface. Keep strokes short, take breaks, and wipe dust often. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Detail Areas Uneven? Use 220 Grit For Plastic Detail Sanding
items.description: If detail areas look uneven on plastic, 220 grit helps blend small transitions and smooth tight spots before finishing. Fold the sheet for control, use short strokes, then wipe clean and inspect under light. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Edges Look Over-Sanded? Refine Plastic Edges With 320 Grit
items.description: If plastic edges look over-sanded, 320 grit helps refine the scratch pattern and smooth the edge appearance before paint or coating. Use very light pressure and short strokes, then wipe clean to inspect. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Tight Spots Hard To Smooth? Use 220 Grit For Detail Work
items.description: When tight spots are hard to smooth on plastic, 220 grit gives control for detail sanding without deep scratches. Fold the sheet into a narrow strip, sand with short strokes, and wipe clean to check. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Plastic Trim Feels Rough? Sand Trim With 220 Grit
items.description: If plastic trim feels rough, 220 grit helps smooth the surface and reduce sanding lines before paint or coating. Use light pressure and long passes to keep the trim even, then wipe clean and inspect. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Small Plastic Parts Hard To Prep? Hand Sand With 220 Grit
items.description: Small plastic parts are hard to prep without digging in. 220 grit works well for hand sanding when you fold the sheet into a small pad and use short, controlled strokes. Wipe clean to inspect often. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Edge Scratches After Prep? Refine Plastic Edges With 320 Grit
items.description: If scratches still show on plastic edges after prep, 320 grit helps refine the scratch pattern for a cleaner edge before paint or coating. Use very light pressure, short strokes, and wipe clean to inspect often. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Details Not Blending In? Use 220 Then 320 Grit On Plastic
items.description: If plastic details aren’t blending in, start with 220 grit to level the transition, then use 320 grit to refine the scratch pattern for a smoother blend. Fold the sheet for control and wipe clean between steps. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Corners Look Too Aggressive? Lightly Sand With 320 Grit
items.description: If plastic corners look too aggressive after sanding, 320 grit helps refine the scratch pattern and smooth the look without deep marks. Use light pressure, short strokes, and rotate your sanding direction. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Edges Need A Final Touch? Finish Plastic Edge Prep With 320 Grit
items.description: When plastic edges just need a final touch, 320 grit helps refine the edge and reduce fine sanding lines before paint or coating. Use very light pressure and a few controlled passes, then wipe clean. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Detail Sanding Leaving Marks? Clean Up Plastic With 320 Grit
items.description: If detail sanding is leaving marks on plastic, 320 grit helps clean up the surface and refine the scratch pattern before finishing. Use light pressure, short strokes, and wipe clean to inspect often. Sandpaper eQualle
